statement.p:
Nutritional information about a breakfast cereal is printed on the box. For instance, one serving of Frosted Flakes has 111 calories, 140 milligrams of sodium, and 1.2 grams of protein. We may represent this as a vector
\left[\begin{array}{r} 111 \\ 140 \\ 1.2 \\ \end{array}\right] . One serving of Cocoa Puffs has 120 calories, 105 milligrams of sodium, and 1.0 grams of protein.
Write the vector describing the nutritional content of Cocoa Puffs.
Suppose you eat c servings of Frosted Flakes and d servings of Cocoa Puffs. Use the language of vectors and linear combinations to express the quantities of calories, sodium, and protein you have consumed.
How many servings of each cereal have you eaten if you have consumed 342 calories, 385 milligrams of sodium, and 3.4 grams of protein.
Suppose your sister consumed 250 calories, 200 milligrams of sodium, and 4 grams of protein. What can you conclude about her breakfast?

li.p: You had two servings of Frosted Flakes and one serving of Cocoa Puffs.
Your sister must have eaten something else.

statement.p:
Consider the vectors
\vvec_1 = \left[\begin{array}{r} 2 \\ -1 \\ -2 \end{array}\right], \vvec_2 = \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ 3 \\ 1 \end{array}\right], \vvec_3 = \left[\begin{array}{r} 4 \\ 4 \\ -2 \end{array}\right].
Can you express the vector \bvec=\left[\begin{array}{r} 10 \\ 1 \\ -8 \end{array}\right] as a linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3? If so, describe all the ways in which you can do so.
Can you express the vector \bvec=\left[\begin{array}{r} 3 \\ 7 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] as a linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3? If so, describe all the ways in which you can do so.
Show that \vvec_3 can be written as a linear combination of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
Explain why any linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3,
a\vvec_1 + b\vvec_2 + c\vvec_3,
can be rewritten as a linear combination of just \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.

li.p:
We have the system corresponding to the augmented matrix
\left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 2 \amp 0 \amp 4 \amp 10 \\ -1 \amp 3 \amp 4 \amp 1 \\ -2 \amp 1 \amp -2 \amp -8 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 5 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right]
from which we conclude that \bvec may be expressed as a linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3 provided that the weights are related by c_1=5-2c_3 and c_2=2-2c_3.
a\vvec_1+b\vvec_2+c\vvec_3=a\vvec_1+b\vvec_2 + c(2\vvec_1+2\vvec_2) = (a+2c)\vvec_1+(b+2c)\vvec_2.
The vector \bvec may be expressed as a linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3 provided that the weights are related by c_1=5-2c_3 and c_2=2-2c_3.
The vector \bvec cannot be written as a linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3.
\vvec_3=2\vvec_1+2\vvec_2.
a\vvec_1+b\vvec_2+c\vvec_3= (a+2c)\vvec_1+(b+2c)\vvec_2.

Suppose \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n is a collection of m-dimensional vectors and that the matrix \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_n \end{array}\right]
has a pivot position in every row and every column. If \bvec is any m-dimensional vector, then \bvec can be written as a linear combination of \vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n in exactly one way.

statement.p:
A theme that will later unfold concerns the use of coordinate systems. We can identify the point (x,y) with the tip of the vector \left[\begin{array}{r}x\\y\end{array}\right], drawn emanating from the origin. We can then think of the usual Cartesian coordinate system in terms of linear combinations of the vectors
\evec_1 = \left[\begin{array}{r} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right], \evec_2 = \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ 1 \end{array}\right].
For instance, the point (2,-3) is identified with the vector \left[\begin{array}{r} 2 \\ -3 \end{array}\right] = 2\evec_1 - 3\evec_2,
